p: The commercial clove oil with the concentration of 0.5–2% inhibited the growth of the stains in the collection ( E. coli ATTC 25922 and E. coli ATTC 10536). The E. coli ATTC 25922 strain proved to be more sensitive, and the growth inhibition zones were 12.5 to 15 mm. On the other hand, the environmental isolate E. coli 127 revealed sensitivity only to higher concentrations of this oil (1.5–2%). However, no biocidal effect was observed of clove extracts against the tested bacterial strains ( Figure 5).
